@Brainmage One thing to mention: HDR support on PC is a pain in the arse in general. Monitors that do a decent fist of it cost an arm and a leg (most don't have the brightness) and then Windows support is a nightmare and games only occasionally support it. Go for resolution + refresh rate.

@Brainmage The Dell S2721DGFA seems like a sweet spot: 27in, 1440p, 165Hz, ~£330. More info (and recommendations for other specs if you want something bigger) @ https://t.co/NnHFdBlNaG

I've not got that Dell, but I've got *a* Dell, and it is excellent. Their monitors are superb.
@Brainmage Anything that uses LG's new fast-switching IPS tech is generally the best balance at the moment, I gather. Decent colours + fast response + good motion clarity.

Just done some rough maths on a take-home-pay calculator. The difference between what my salary is and what my salary should be is, post-tax... £498 a month.

FIVE HUNDRED QUID A MONTH

THEY ARE STIFFING ME FOR
FIVE
H U N D R E D
P . O . U . N . D . S

EVERY
SINGLE
MONTH
Addendum: looked up the actual figures for my job, worked it out directly, oh fucking dear: https://t.co/DBa6anapGK
Just one more tiny way they're screwing us, I guess, on top of the Very Big Way.

*this is not a typo--they have only just agreed the pay package for April 2021 onwards. They will backdate this, but this does mean that, every year, I am having to pay for the increased cost of living without the pay rise to accommodate that increased cost of living.

And yet I am, effectively, in real terms, only earning 80.2% of the salary for it that I used to.

I am working Friday for free.

In 13 years this role has had a cumulative 14.5% cost-of-living rise while inflation has been a cumulative 42.7%. It's the same job. If anything the requirements and pressures have grown as schools make more and more use of IT; it's part of the essential fabric, now.
Oh. https://t.co/2xuT3Z9wrP
In 2018 that SCP 38 pay point was relabelled as SCP 32, so let's look up SCP 32 in the newly agreed NJC package for April 2021* onwards, shall we? https://t.co/uTOYjFpwgo
Plug £31,754 into the Bank of England's Inflation Calculator, and in 2021 that should be £45,321.96: https://t.co/3SgFuxy90M
You can Google up old NJC scales fairly easily; councils etc. distribute them widely. Here's a copy of 2009's scale; SCP 38 is £31,754. https://t.co/iJ2rCPH2Hj

Have realised that, as I'm on the NJC pay scale, I can look up actual figures!

My current pay point is SCP 32 on the NJC scale. In 2018 they reorganised the scales, so this SCP 32 used to be labelled SCP 38. (This will make sense in a moment.) Source: https://t.co/AUXw1hi3gw https://t.co/N9IvhEdNOL

@Gledster It should not be impossible to be happy simply existing. We shouldn't have to be constantly striving and switching job and climbing a ladder we've no interest in seeing the top of.

And presumably they need someone down here anyway, else the job wouldn't exist at all!

@lbrothers tbf  I can well believe that many people simply couldn't afford strike action. The union may have waited too many years to call for it and now we're past the tipping point where we're too low paid to afford to strike over low pay.

@jkcheney It's getting so difficult. The system is grinding me down, and I'm already ground down enough that I haven't the energy to fight it any more--ironically, in large part because I overworked so much thru the pandemic to keep things running!

@Gledster Of course it's our fault for the choices we've made--unlike the Tories, we chose not to act selfishly and only for our own enrichment, consequences be damned. We tried to choose something better, and are getting punished for it.
@lbrothers I'm guessing they didn't get the numbers on the strike ballot they sent out.

Think about us next time you are at the ballot box. We keep the country running, and we do it because we want to do something important, something better than just making money. We are the ones who worked through lockdowns and risked our lives and loved ones. We deserve better.

And this calculus is the same for pretty much all public sector employees--nurses have had it even worse than us, with multiple pay freezes. MPs, of course, continue to get regular and significant increases.

Let us not forget that they screwed us over on our pensions a few years back, too, so they've broken the old public sector trade-off of knowing you're getting lower pay through your career but have a better cushion in retirement. Now I'm just lower paid throughout.

I now effectively work one day for free for this government.

I am good at my job. I love my job. I am struggling to afford to stay in my job.

So yeah. My reward, as with all school support staff, for dragging this country's education system through a pandemic and keeping it running for the sake of the kids in the face of negligence and outright corruption from central government is... a 5% paycut. On top of a 16% cut.

And all this is assuming the rate-of-inflation accurately measures the changes on the cost-of-living for those of us at the lower end of the earning scale, which--as @BootstrapCook's recent work has shown--is very unlikely. So I'm probably even worse off than this shows.

Divide those two and it turns out that, relatively speaking, my job is now only worth 83% of what it was a decade ago. A full *sixth* less.

My job is not 1/6th easier than it was a decade ago. It does not take 1/6th less of my time or energy. Very much the opposite, in fact.

And to be clear on what the Tories in power looks like for working families:
💷 Since 2010, cumulative inflation has been 36.4% (source: Bank of England calculator)
💷 Since 2010, I've had no more than 1% cost-of-living increase a year. Cumulatively, that's 13.5%.

Email from the union. They've accepted the pathetic 1.75% pay offer from the NJC.

That's a 1.75% increase to cover the cost of living versus:
📈 7.1% inflation
📈 +30% year-on-year increase in diesel
📈 upcoming 50% hike on energy bills
📈 10% increase to NI contributions

Fuck.

This mini-thread dedicated to the narrator on the Mote in God's Eye audiobook whose Scottish accent was so atrocious it stopped my attempt to get through the classics dead. Saved me a lot of wasted time.

If you've managed to arrange a situation wherein you intend to be published in 1961 then by all means the classics are more important, but also, I think there are better uses for that tech you've got than SFF publishing, this is a terrible get rich scheme

I mean read 'em if you want, certainly there are some I enjoy--Dune and 1984 and anything PKD--but any attempt to declare them "essential" is bullshit and a waste of your time, if you're trying to write now then read what's being published *now*

My take on the whole classics disk horse is that 90% of the Golden Age classics I've read were boring af and written in a style that's no longer in fashion and thus irrelevant to anyone writing now; they will, in fact, lead you astray

Anyway. This is Luke Jerram's Museum of the Moon, as displayed in Lincoln Cathedral, and if you get a chance to see it, well, you should. It's part of a species-long journey to understanding ourselves. It's a journey we should all walk, so far as our time takes us.
it's a moment. A moment made of epochs.
to see that, in the context of something we can understand, something built in the pursuit of understanding our place in this enormous, infinite, impossible universe:
...something that humans have looked up to and wondered at since there was anything even halfway recognisable as human, a constant across our entire evolution--

And to see a representation of the Moon--the smallest and nearest of our celestial neighbours, the most ever present, the most comprehensible, and yet still ageless and enormous beyond understanding...
Of recognising that the universe around us is so big and so baffling and so beyond us, that we are at once the centre of everything in our own perception and also unfathomably small
And yes on the face of it that "something bigger" is a god that doesn't exist, imho, but looked at from another angle--my angle--that "something bigger" is the terror of the sublimity of creation
I'm not a religious person in the least. I'm an atheist twice over. But I love cathedrals, because they represent continuity, connection between the generations, and a commitment to something bigger.
Just. What a sight. What a setting. https://t.co/a9FSjTgpjo

1) Type about:config in the URL bar

@chronicleflask I don't fucking know how this has happened. It's the first time strike action has been balloted since academisation (I was still LEA last time), but it's several shades of bullshit.

I'm in the union for other reasons too, but this is so frustrating.

I've not really got a capstone for this thread, it's mostly just venting about how the Tories continue to grind us down and divide us and weaken us, but FWIW: fight for every scrap of unionised power you can get. It's often the only power we have, and now we're losing that too.

As it stands I'm not actually sure if I can even take part in the strike action if it's called; I've asked my local branch but they've not answered yet

(cc @unisontheunion, any ideas if academy staff ineligible for balloting re: NJC pay can still strike?)
(I say "loophole" as if it weren't a deliberately conceived consequence of the policy...)

We follow the terms and conditions of the NJC, including the pay awards. I am affected, in every way, by these negotations. But because of a bullshit loophole arising from a government policy of removing schools from local control, I am not allowed to influence these negotiations

But here's the kicker: when I followed up about where my ballot paper was, it turns out I'm not eligible to vote.

Because my school is no longer a local authority school, but an academy, it is technically not party to the national negotiations between the gov and the NJC.

Now I am a member of a union, for many reasons. And as the years have gone on I have become more militant about and commited to the ideals of worker solidarity.

I am pleased to say my union, Unison, is balloting for strike action.

And what is my reward for this mind-breaking labour, this phenomenal act of effort to ensure the students were still educated, still connected, still cared for?

A pay offer of 1.75% against a CPI inflation rate of 5.1%. Another pay cut.

(Source: https://t.co/Yokec6RSp5)

And so I work in schools, and probably give too much of myself.

And then COVID hit, and I worked so damn hard keeping this school running (I'm the man what does the computers) that I burned out and probably permanently damaged myself on a mental and emotional level.

But, unfortunately, I have a deep moral belief that I ought to do something meaningful with my labour. I would not be able to rest easy if I worked solely to make a rich person even richer, or in an enterprise that contributed to climate collapse, war profiteering, w/e
That is, in real terms, a 20% pay cut to my job. It has not gotten 20% easier. I am not working 20% fewer hours. And yet my time is valued at 20% less, in real terms, than it was a decade ago.
Between 2010 and 2020, inflation averaged 2.7%, cumulatively about 31.1% (source: Bank of England inflation calculator https://t.co/G7iRbahzcK) https://t.co/RSbNlMo7jf
Generally speaking, our negotiated cost-of-living pay increase has been either 0.5% or 1%. Over 10 years that's cumulatively about 7.8%: https://t.co/6prRq3fCf9

So here's some bullshit for you:

I work in a school. My pay is negotiated nationally, like all UK school workers, with the government by the National Joint Council.

Since 2010 and the advent of "austerity", these negotations have been thoroughly demoralising.

Anyway. Hopefully this fear is misplaced, born of the same neurodivergent anxieties that will keep me honest and working to avoid the fuck ups in the first place. I hope I do the stories proud, and do justice to the role. It really is an enormous honour.

I'm not saying don't call me out. I will fuck up in ways you ought to draw my attention to! I have done in the past! I'm just asking that you give me space to apologise properly, and learn, and grow.

I'm not tone policing. I just... hope everyone remembers I'm human too.

I almost turned down the opportunity because I have seen one too many Twitter mobs on here of late, and I do not want to find myself at the eye of that storm.

But fear is a terrible reason not to do things.
But I would be lying to you and me both if I pretended every fuck up is avoidable. So I ask, please, for your patience and your forgiveness of my ignorance.

But, inevitably... I will fuck it up sometimes. I was born imperfect, I will die imperfect, so for all the bits inbetween I will be imperfect. I will always try my best, and I am always trying to get better, be more aware, be more conscious of my place and privilege in the world.
I owe it to the author and the audience both to do that right. I promise I will try my best with every story.

More so than most (any?) other venues, the @EAPodcasts truly do present a story to the world: we don't just put it out there, we introduce it personally, and provide the space for it to rattle round your head afterwards.

Being host is a big thing. Not just following in the footsteps of incredible people like @scribblesassin, @kibitzer, @krylyr, @ann_leckie, @rachelswirsky, M. K. Hobson and Anna Schwind, but... being the person to present a story to the world. That's a responsibility.
I am honoured and terrified and delighted and nervous and privileged and overthinking EVERYTHING

Good gods above. It was good as a single player game, but with that fleeting, tenuous, indescribable connection to a stranger it's... just transcendent. Utterly unlike anything else as an experience.

It is such a significant, symbolic, meaningful point that the only means you have of communication also restores and fuels you both. Gives you grace and elegance, the means with which to pick yourself up and soar through the world

And yet it ends up meaning so much.

Thank you for the company, Karakara, whomever and wherever you are https://t.co/Kr0iD3xemx

Good grief. That is qualitatively different with someone alongside you. Someone with whom you have the barest connection, only silent action and a single ping to say I Am Here, and You Are Here, and I See You

*so fast. Getting back to my buddy mattered more than spelling, sorry.

And now we're finished, and will never have that connection again. We don't even know who each other are. Yet we pinged to each other every step of that final moment.

@stuartcturnbull Journey. Sometimes, out of nowhere, with no rhyme or reason or request, you find yourself playing alongside someone else. You can do nothing except ping at each other as a simple hello. As an I Am Here. As company and acknowledgement. And it is so astonishingly moving.

@CJDwriter @audibleuk So getting annoyed at this "promotion" of certain titles out of genre *is* defending genre: it's believing that there's nothing in it to be ashamed of.

@CJDwriter @audibleuk "...they're not really science fiction anymore! You don't need to sully yourself in the genre weeds to enjoy them!"

Which is the same intellectual snobbery that leads to e.g. Kazuo Ishiguro declaring The Buried Giant isn't fantasy, despite having a bloody dragon in it

@CJDwriter @audibleuk My real issue, though, is this implication that Fiction is the "real" category, to which the most successful and acclaimed titles can aspire; by including some in Fiction it's saying "these are the ones we think are good enough for *normal* people; they're so good...

@CJDwriter @audibleuk And so what's to be gained by putting Sirens of Titan in fiction? Anyone looking for the aforementioned Nadine Dorries titles isn't going to be interested in the least; meanwhile people like me who *are* interested, won't ever discovery it in the wrong category.

@CJDwriter @audibleuk If all speculative fiction is simply fiction--and I agree! And with the converse!--then why have separate categories at all?

Because genre is a marketing tool. It's a way to ease discoverability. It's a way to set expectations and smooth the path to your purchase.

Apropos of another Matt mega-thread, https://t.co/F5upo6A6xp is by far the best way to draft a thread. Gives you character counts, previews, and lets you do it all in plain text, controlling new tweets just with line breaks. Not long found it, but I'm a fan.
If we want to get something more out of it than fucking commercials, we need to consider our actions and the repurcussions thereof. We need to be good citizens.
We can use Twitter better, but we have to be conscious in our engagement here, because the platform itself is working against us. It drives outrage to drive engagement to drive advertising revenues.

I am tired of seeing so many excellent people driven away by the architecture of rage + righteousness that Twitter foments. I beg you: notice how many voices went quiet since the IF/NY fallout. They weren't necessarily voices that were involved. They just watched, and noped out.

Anyway, I can't comment more on the situation because it's pivoted from a public spectacle to a behind-closed-doors issue. I'm posting this in the interests of, please dear gods please, some of us maybe learning some lessons about how to use this platform better.
vi) I love colons and semi-colons too much.
v) Twitter has the attention span of a small kitten. If you stay still long enough it will get distracted by something else; if you keep moving and twitching it will keep scratching you.

(iv cont.) (at one point Twitter-the-platform asked if I wanted to set up filters for our notifications because it was such a barrage. It felt overwhelming *even from the perspective of the supported party*. Imagine how it feels when you're the target.)

iv) When you're in the circus and engaging one-on-one with the other party, it's easy to forget how many people are doing the same in parallel. Those numbers quickly become overwhelming. Consider whether it's productive to add to them.

iii) Related to the above: if you're in the circus, bear in mind that the people alongside you who seem most vociferous are potentially the least relevant and least involved. Keep your head and don't let them lead you astray.
ii) One that we should all know from history, but seem to forget here: you can't control the mob. Half of it doesn't even care who you are, or what your cause is: they just enjoy being part of a mob.

Lessons?

i) One I'd learned before but that helped yesterday: Twitter as a platform creates a pressure to respond rapidly. Taking a moment to think and respond well is way more important.
(6 cont.) It's not just "don't feed the trolls"--it's "don't feed the flames".

(6 cont.) As far as we're concerned the best way to kill the conversation now--which from our perspective has run its course; Forbes have offered every restitution it is in their power to offer--is to starve it of oxygen. A new story will sweep through soon.

6) If the situation is continuing to unfold, it is because one party is continuing to respond. Given that the people keeping the fire burning are, again, randos not bothering to check for updates to the situation first, there's not a lot to be gained from continuing this defence.

5) Further to (2) and (3), despite repeated appeals for calm and trying to put the public situation to bed, we're largely powerless to stop people continuing the fight. This is certainly related to the drive-by randos.

4) Further to (3), some of the most relentless and angry responses were from these randos. I suspect that any mob you see has a not-insignificant proportion of these provocateurs. Bear that in mind next time you feel yourself getting swept up in one.

3) Further to (2), plenty of the responses were from people who didn't follow us and had no mutuals. The PodCastle account is pretty well connected into the short SFF community, so no mutuals at all suggests they're complete randos.

2) at a certain point people are joining in for the sake of enjoying a pile on. Easy dopamine. There was a clear wrong, they can easily have a pop, they want to join in. It didn't matter that the article was corrected and an apology posted. They didn't look; they just responded.

1) you never know what will light a fire under the circus. I've posted half-a-dozen similarly exasperated + sarcastic responses to people "borrowing" the name and never had one take off like this before. I wasn't trying to provoke a response, but: Twitter is a tinderbox.

Couple of quick observations about how Twitter behaves, based on yesterday's PodCastle stuff. This was ultimately a pretty low stakes situation--one incorrect throwaway line in an article--so it's safe and easy to dissect.
